content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
How can you finance your education strategically
to maximize opportunity while minimizing debt?

objectives.description: Compare various post-secondary financing options including scholarships, grants, federal loans, private loans, and work-study programs.
Describe the purpose and process of completing the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) and why early submission matters.
Analyze federal vs. private student loan options, including terms, interest rates, repayment plans, and forgiveness programs.
Develop a balanced financial plan that prioritizes non-debt financing options and aligns with long-term financial goals.

leftPanel.title: Why Strategic Planning Matters
paragraphs: Post-secondary education is a significant investment that can open doors to enhanced career opportunities and higher earning potential.
However, without a clear plan, students can end up with overwhelming debt that limits future financial choices for decades.
The decisions you make now about financing will have long-term implications for your financial well-being.

highlightBox.text: � Education is an investmentâ€”but smart investors minimize unnecessary costs while maximizing returns.

items: Requires effort to find and apply

items: Interest starts accruing immediately or upon graduation
Easier to access (which can be risky)

leftPanel.title: Strategic Funding Approach
paragraphs: The most effective approach to financing education involves a combination of funding sources in strategic priority order.
Always exhaust "free money" options before considering loans. When loans are necessary, federal options typically offer better terms than private loans.

highlightBox.text: � Rule of thumb: Every dollar in scholarships is a dollar you don't have to borrowâ€”or repay with interest!

layoutData.title: Understanding Your Loan Options
paragraphs: If borrowing is necessary, federal loans should always be your first choice. They offer significant advantages over private loans.
bulletPoints: Federal Subsidized: Government pays interest while you're in school (need-based)
Federal Unsubsidized: Available to all students; interest accrues immediately
Income-Driven Repayment: Federal loans offer flexible plans based on your income
Loan Forgiveness: Public Service Loan Forgiveness after 120 qualifying payments
Private Loans: Higher rates, less flexibility, often require cosigner
Credit Checks: Federal loans don't require credit history; private loans do

leftPanel.title: Why FAFSA Is Essential
paragraphs: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the primary gateway to nearly all federal financial aid.
Completing the FAFSA determines eligibility for federal grants, loans, and work-study. Many states and colleges also use it to award their own aid.
Even if you think your family makes "too much," always complete the FAFSAâ€”you may qualify for aid you didn't expect.

highlightBox.text: � Opens October 1st each year. Submit earlyâ€”some aid is first-come, first-served!

content.headerTitle: Why This Matters for Your Future

layoutData.title: Education Financing = Life Choices
paragraphs: The financing decisions you make for education have far-reaching implications for your financial future. Understanding your options allows you to balance educational quality with financial reality.
bulletPoints: Starting Salaries: College graduates earn ~$1M more over their lifetime on average
Monthly Payments: Average student loan payment is $200-$400/month for 10-25 years
Career Flexibility: High debt may force you to take jobs for salary, not passion
Strategic Choices: Community college â†’ transfer can save $(({{STATE_TUITION_PUBLIC}} - {{STATE_TUITION_COMMUNITY}}) * 2)+ with same degree in {{STATE_NAME}}
Loan Forgiveness: Public service careers may qualify for forgiveness programs
Compound Effect: Money not spent on loans can be invested for your future

leftPanel.title: Scholarships Aren't Just for "Perfect" Students
paragraphs: One of the biggest misconceptions is that scholarships are only for students with perfect grades or exceptional athletic ability.
In reality, scholarships exist for nearly every interest, background, and talentâ€”from community service to unusual hobbies to specific career paths.
The key is starting early and applying strategically. Treat scholarship applications like a part-time job.

scenario.name: Jordan's Scholarship-Focused Approach
paragraphs: Jordan, a high school senior with strong academics and leadership experience, created a systematic approach starting junior year. Jordan researched 50 potential scholarships and dedicated 5 hours weekly to applications.

scenario.name: Casey's Balanced Funding Strategy
paragraphs: Casey came from a middle-income family that couldn't save much for college. Instead of taking on maximum loans, Casey created a strategic multi-year plan for nursing school:
Year 1: Community college while living at homeâ€”Pell Grant ($2,500), merit scholarship ($1,500), part-time pharmacy job ($8,000). Zero loans, money saved.
Years 2-4: Transferred to university nursing program with transfer scholarship ($3,000), nursing scholarship ($2,000), hospital work-study, and limited federal loans ($5,500/year).
